properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today and tonight. Heavy bursts of snow associated with the passage of a low pressure system could affect road conditions and visibilities this morning. In the early afternoon cold westerly and northwesterly winds will generate lake effect snow squalls that could persist until midnight. These snow squall bands will continuously shift over the region which will limit the snowfall amount over a given location. A total snowfall accumulation of 5 to 10 cm is expected by Wednesday morning. Locally higher snowfall amounts are also possible. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to heavy snow and blowing snow. Difficult winter travel conditions are expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-20T01:02:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-19T09:03:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4282484325.2021
Area: Midland - Coldwater - Orr Lake, Orillia - Lagoon City - Washago, Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park, Port Carling - Port Severn, Bracebridge - Gravenhurst
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Update : Male Wanted On Multiple Warrants Armed With A Firearm.
properties.Summary:
Description: Update :The RCMP continue their search in Meat Cove Nova Scotia for Perry MACKINNON date of birth October 9 1986 caucasian male 5 foot 9 inches weight 199 pounds last seen wearing a dark coloured jacket and jogging pants Large RCMP presence in area MACKINNON is wanted on multiple warrants and has fled with a firearm into a wooded area in Meat Cove If MACKINNON is seen do not approach Call 9-1-1 We ask that you continue to remain indoors and await further updates
Expires: 2021-01-19T19:00:00-04:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Province of NS, 2021-01-18T19:19:05-04:00, C82DFDA1-1DDF-DE4B-42FF-97CAD9C20927
Area: Update : Meat Cove Nova Scotia
properties.Author: Province of NS

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds, with gusts up to 110 km/h, will develop this afternoon. The strongest winds will subside late this evening. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and widespread blowing snow expected Wednesday. Total snowfall: 15 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h or higher. Locations: northern Labrador. Time span: Wednesday morning through Thursday morning. Remarks: Snow will develop across coastal Labrador overnight Tuesday night and become heavy at times on Wednesday. This fresh snowfall will be accompanied by very strong northwesterly winds and cold temperatures to bring widespread blowing snow to these regions. Conditions are expected to improve overnight Wednesday night and into Thursday morning as winds begin to ease. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-19T18:17:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-19T02:18:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2543302316.2021
Area: Postville - Makkovik, Hopedale and vicinity, Nain and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong low pressure system tracking toward Foxe Basin is bringing strong winds, snow and blowing snow. Strong northerly winds with gusts to 70 km/h along with snow and blowing snow will create a blizzard beginning this morning that will last until this evening in Coral Harbour and until Wednesday morning in Naujaat. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Freezing Rain Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain has developed tonight and is expected to continue for several hours leading to icy conditions. The freezing rain will taper off overnight but temperatures are expected to remain below freezing leading to slippery conditions into early morning. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Freezing rain warnings are issued when rain falling in sub-zero temperatures creates ice build-up and icy surfaces. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-19T14:23:50-00:00

Area: Fort Nelson

A blizzard warning is issued when winds are expected to produce blowing snow with widespread visibilities of 400 metres or less for at least 6 hours. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected this afternoon. Winds will rise to southwest 70 km/h gusting to 90 early this afternoon and will ease early in the evening. A cold front will sweep across the BC Peace River today. Gusty winds will rise through the morning, peaking in the afternoon. The strongest winds are expected to ease by the evening, however gusty westerly winds will likely continue through the night in the wake of the front. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-20T03:49:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-19T11:50:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1010866723.2021
Area: B.C. South Peace River, B.C. North Peace River

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential winter storm beginning Thursday. Total estimated snowfall: 15 cm or more. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h or higher. Locations: Avalon Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity and Bonavista Peninsula. Time span: Thursday afternoon into Friday. Remarks: A storm is expected to form south of Nova Scotia on Wednesday and track east of Newfoundland Thursday and Friday. Snow is expected to spread across Newfoundland Thursday afternoon, accompanied by strong winds and areas of blowing snow. Blizzard-like conditions are possible Thursday afternoon and night. Conditions will improve on Friday. There is still uncertainty regarding the track of this storm, which will have a significant impact on snowfall amounts. Should the storm pass further east, snowfall amounts will be much less, while if it tracks closer to the Avalon, higher accumulations will be expected. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-01-20T06:05:32-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-19T14:06:32-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3096133140.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

This fresh snowfall will be accompanied by very strong northwesterly winds and cold temperatures to bring near-zero visibilities. Conditions are expected to improve overnight Wednesday night and into Thursday morning as winds begin to ease and snow tapers off. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow squalls expected this afternoon and tonight. Snow squalls are expected to develop behind a cold front this afternoon. Under these snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow. Total snowfall accumulations of 15 to 20 cm are possible in some locales by Wednesday midday when the snow squalls taper to flurries. In addition, strong westerly winds gusting to 50 km/h will result in local blowing snow and may cause near-zero visibility at times. ### Snow squalls cause weather conditions to vary considerably; changes from clear skies to heavy snow within just a few kilometres are common. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-20T01:04:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-01-19T09:05:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4155111024.2021

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. A deep low pressure system is moving through the region. As a result, heavy snow and strong winds have developed over the Haines Road and South Klondike Highway. The storm will continue to rage into the night. The snow and winds will eventually abate early Tuesday morning. Snow fall accumulation near 25 cm is expected. ### Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.

Locations: Coastal Labrador from Lodge Bay to Rigolet. Time span: early Wednesday morning until Wednesday evening. Conditions will improve as the winds and snow ease Wednesday night. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for this morning and early this afternoon.. Snow and local blowing snow this morning may affect road conditions and visibilities making travel difficult. Heavy snow associated with a low pressure system will move through the area early this morning, This snow will quickly be followed by the development of lake effect snow this morning. Local blowing snow will also lead to reduced visibilities. Local snowfall accumulations near 10 cm are likely before the heaviest band of lake effect snow pushes south of the area early this afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-01-19T21:12:36-00:00
